issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

fields.summary: Internal server error on fresh install of eucaconsole

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description: This is customer affecting. I believe python-nss affected beaker negatively and we should look at patching beaker, and possibly distributing our patched version on our repo.

comments.body: [~dkavanagh] is 4.4. a reasonable release target for this fix?

[~tony] if this can be fixed by patching beaker and publishing our own package, then the tasks around packaging may take longer to put in place. I will have a look on Monday (sooner if it's really pressing, let me know).

I verified that [~mcrawford]'s solution of exporting an environment variable in our init script does work.

export NSS_STRICT_NOFORK=DISABLED

I would like to research this a bit more to ensure it's validity. That would be a much lighter-weight solution than patching beaker.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/Python_binding_for_NSS
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS

While the fix seems to work, I would really like to find this as a documented feature, so we can rely on it.

This code in the nss library sets the value:
https://hg.mozilla.org/projects/nss/file/2ed8aef0b360/cmd/pk11mode/pk11mode.c

This code uses it:
https://hg.mozilla.org/projects/nss/file/2ed8aef0b360/lib/softoken/softoken.h

so far, feels like an internal value, not documented external thing.

Phew, found this:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/Reference/NSS_environment_variables

This documents this and what it does, so I feel better about using it. I'll submit a PR.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole-rpmspec/pull/20

I read through the NSS_environment_variables link above, and it seems this fix disables a security improvement by reverting to prior version behavior. I think that while this is likely satisfactory for a workaround to our current problem with beaker, we should "put in a reminder" (however we might do that) to review the necessity of keeping this workaround on each new release, so once beaker (or ?) is fixed to work without the need for this, we can remove it and obtain the more secure behavior.
Given the security impact of that fix, I think we should get [~rusvika]'s opinion before merging it.
ping [~rusvika]

My main concern is that by disabling this variable we allow for an error condition and side effect is not well defined.
It looks like this issue was fixed in RHEL 7 [recently|https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1317691]. If an updated nss library is used, does the issue still exist?

I tested this by installing packages on a CentOS 7 machine on Dec 5th. The fix you linked was Nov 3rd. I checked and what's installed on that machine is:
 python-nss          x86_64          0.16.0-3.el7            base          266 k

What's referred to in the linked advisory : https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHBA-2016-2335.html
is: nss-3.21.0-17.el7.i686.rpm
It doesn't seem like this is available on CentOS 7 yet?

Back to your concern. We're not allowing an error condition, we're preventing the code from forking in the way it default to. It's avoiding the error by not allowing the conditions that cause it. Does that concern you still?

[~dkavanagh], my understanding of the variable NSS_STRICT_NOFORK is that if it's set to DISABLE, it will ignore an error condition "to try to use a PKCS#11 crypto module in a process before it has been initialized in that process, even if the module was initialized in the parent process". So, while it works around our problem, it will ignore an error condition if one is ever encountered, right?

nss-3.21.0-17.el7.i686.rpm is available on Centos 7, are you sure that's not what was installed on your machine during testing?.

Upon re-reading the documentation for that flag, yes, I think it is simply ignoring the initialization error. I'll fire up a new Centos7 instance to see if the updated python-nss is available, or we need to provide additional instructions for those using python-nss to get the newer version.

On a centos 7 setup that I ran "yum update" on, running "yum install python-nss" still gives me this version:
 python-nss          x86_64          0.16.0-3.el7            base          266 k
Build Date  : Fri 20 Nov 2015 03:21:23 AM UTC

[~rusvika], how were you able to see the newer version on CentOS? Did you add a special repo?

[~dkavanagh], the advisory talks about nss not python-nss package (hence, the version difference). The updated nss is available on Centos 7, but I don't know if it can help with the issue we're seeing ...
Oh, that's true! I suspect I was using the updated NSS at the time I tested then, but will try testing again. I forgot that python-nss is simply a wrapper for the nss package.

Seeing same error when this nss installed:
Name        : nss
Version     : 3.21.3
Release     : 2.el7_3

Let's talk about what's at stake. This change just doesn't report the initialization error in forked processes. The code functions fine, as in it encrypts/decrypts the session token properly. What's the concern? I wasn't clear if there were security implications from reading the bug report you linked to.

My understanding of the error condition is that a forked process might be using uninitialized or not properly initialized structure, what these structures are is not defined. Depending on what these structs contain, we can run in all sorts of crypto problems, which is bad. Have you tried opening a bug for python-nss? I think if there is no better solution than to disable to the NOFORK var in 4.4.0, we should actively figure out a proper fix.
We always have the option of patching beaker to stop it from using nss in favor of pycryptopp which is what we normally use.
[~dkavanagh], assigning it back to you to figure out the best solution for 4.4.0.

Question for [~gholms]. We don't co-exist with python-nss / nss well due to an issue in nss that wasn't fixed (for our app) with the latest nss release. Vika is concerned about the unknowns in our workaround (from the PR linked in the comments). Two options remaining:
 - get nss fixed properly by either working with dev team or patching and submitting PR. Filing a bug is 1st step.
 - since Beaker uses nss if it's available, we could patch Beaker to not attempt that and put our own patched beaker in our repo. The lines of code involved make a patch to that very reasonable: https://github.com/bbangert/beaker/blob/master/beaker/crypto/__init__.py#L19-L22
I feel like getting nss fixed is a longer term task. Is it reasonable to take the patched beaker route?

[~gholms], looks like we're already carrying this. Do we apply any other patches?
http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/nightly/4.4/rhel/7/x86_64/python-beaker18-1.8.0-1.el7.noarch.rpm

We currently carry no patches for that package.  You can find what patches we apply by inspecting the source package:  http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/nightly/4.4/rhel/7/source/python-beaker18-1.8.0-1.el7.src.rpm

Patching the nss imports out sounds reasonable to me.  Does upstream still fully support pycryptopp?  If so, does switching to it for AES have any significant side effects?
We have been running with pycryptopp since 4.3 when we moved to beaker 1.8 and CentOS 7.
Fixed in python-beaker18-1.8.1-0.1.el7

I tested this on a 4.4 console package installation on CentOS on UFS host.  UFS: 10.111.1.22

Steps:

1) yum install python-nss -y

at this point console is still useable

2) service eucaconsole restart or systemctl restart eucaconsole

Internal server error is displayed.

Error seen in the eucaconsole.log:

{code}

I had no issues. Here's how I installed the console on a fresh centos7 instance I ran.

    1  yum install http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/nightly/4.4/rhel/7/x86_64/eucalyptus-release-nightly-4.4-1.el7.noarch.rpm
    2  yum install -y eucaconsole
    3  vi /etc/eucaconsole//console.ini 
    4  systemctl start eucaconsole.service


I was able to see login screen, login and see dashboard. I should point out that python-nss was also installed after this, and the console restarted.

Seems like we have an upgrade issue.

I ran these:
    1  yum install http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/nightly/4.3/rhel/7/x86_64/eucalyptus-release-nightly-4.3-1.el7.noarch.rpm 
    2  yum install -y eucaconsole
    3  vi /etc/eucaconsole/console.ini 
    4  systemctl start eucaconsole.service
    8  yum install python-nss
    9  systemctl restart eucaconsole.service
   10  yum install -y http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/nightly/4.4/rhel/7/x86_64/eucalyptus-release-nightly-4.4-1.el7.noarch.rpm
   11  yum update eucaconsole
   12  yum upgrade eucaconsole

After step 9, console shows "internal server error"
11 and 12 both indicate "no packages marked for update". How should I upgrade the console?

"yum clean all" was required.
Still getting "internal server error" with upgraded console. Investigating.

[~dkavanagh] please make sure to run "yum clean all" between step 10 and 11, it caches information about the old eucalyptus-release-nightly repository, and when you upgrade to the 4.4 nightly repo, you have to remove that old cached data.

After upgrade, I see:
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Beaker-1.8.0-py2.7.egg
We should have beaker 1.8.1 installed, not 1.8.0. 
The spec file shows 1.8.1
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole-rpmspec/blob/master/eucaconsole.spec#L78

You are still running eucaconsole 4.3.1.  It seems the maint-4.3 branch of eucalyptus-rpmspec never merged into maint-4.4, so the nightly builds were never considered upgrades over 4.3.1.  The latest build should fix that.
Assigned to dkavanagh by gholms

I ran "yum upgrade eucaconsole" on the system that was running 4.3.1 and it upgraded successfully. Further, I get the login screen and am able to login to the application.
I see /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Beaker-1.8.1-py2.7.egg is installed.
This machine also has python-nss-0.16.0-3.el7.x86_64 installed.
